awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Sediment connectivity and its morphologic and vegetative controls: Linking soils and streams in mountain landscapes of the northern Rockies
awd_abstract_narration:
Sediment movement across mountain watersheds influences landscape evolution, ecosystem function, and resource management, yet quantitative understanding of sediment connectivity between hillslopes, streams, and downstream is limited. This project will advance understanding of the pace and patterns of and controls on sediment routing and connectivity in mountain watersheds. The resulting process knowledge will be relevant to management and restoration in forested, fire-prone mountain landscapes, as well as to assessment of aquatic habitat in mountain streams and vulnerability to sediment-related disturbances and climate change. Outreach efforts will include development and delivery of webinars targeted toward K-12 teachers, an interactive science-museum exhibit, and dissemination via digital educational resources. The project will also educate and train university students at the undergraduate and graduate levels.

This project will investigate the influences of topography and vegetation on sediment transfer, residence time, and connectivity between hillslopes, streams, and downstream through river networks. Semiarid, snowmelt-dominated, fire-prone landscapes will be targeted. Measurements of erosion and sediment transport at different scales, using isotopic and physical tracers, will be combined with high-resolution topographic data and modeling of sediment storage, mixing, and routing. The project will fill knowledge gaps surrounding multi-scale erosion rates and processes in mountain landscapes by bridging hillslope and fluvial analyses, combining diverse and cutting-edge tools, and incorporating ecogeomorphic perspectives about the influence of vegetation on sediment transfer.

por.por_cntn:
The sediments found in rivers and floodplains represent a diverse collection of grains, each with its own history and journey from soils to streams and down through river networks. These sediments both reflect and influence landscape-shaping processes, and act as substrate for terrestrial and aquatic life, tools for erosion when scoured across bedrock, or potential pollutants to water supplies and fish when too abundant. Despite the importance of sediment movement to a range of questions about landscape processes, most of our understanding of the fundamental controls focuses solely on the hillslope or stream domains, rather than the continuum and their connectivity. This study aimed to determine the pace and pathways that sediment moves in mountainous landscapes, starting with its genesis in soils on hillslopes and through its transitions across river networks. We sought to understand the role of vegetation and landscape form in influencing sediment transfer, focusing on mountain ranges along the Bitterroot River Basin in SW Montana USA, a study area that presents valuable contrasts in past and present climate, vegetation, soil cover, and landscape morphology.

We used field observations, geochemical and geospatial (GIS) analyses, and digital and physical modeling to characterize and quantify sediment processes within hillslopes, into streams, and through river systems. Beginning with soil formation on mountain slopes, we found that hillslope steepness influences both the intensity of rock weathering and soil residence times and also developed a new way to quantify chemical weathering that accounts for bedrock exposures at both local and landscape scales. We also found that vegetation influences soil residence on slopes in two ways. Firstly, forests store thicker soils for longer timescales than non-forested slopes, even when topography is held constant. Furthermore, though high-intensity fires can drive rapid erosion off of slopes and into streams when vegetation is removed, if abundant woody debris is left on the ground, it can offset up to the equivalent of 200 years of soil erosion.

Where hills meet streams, we found that channel heads were likely less efficient sites of sediment connectivity compared to slopes directly entering larger streams, an important finding considering the emphasis placed on the former in past research regarding connectivity. Within the stream network, we found that coarse wood played an important role in storing sediment and that this storage varied with both the channel type and the orientation and amount of wood in individual channel segments. We also produced models to predict how sediment moves through channel networks. The Sediment Routing and Floodplain Exchange (SeRFE) model simulates sediment supply, transport, and storage at the reach scale and can be applied across drainage basins, providing river practitioners a tool to understand sediment regimes and how disturbances such as fire alter those dynamics. A second model presents a new formula for predicting mixed-size sediment transport in coarse-bedded mountain rivers.

The results of this project provide new insight into the evolution of mountainous landscapes, including drivers and variability of geomorphic processes and the influence of disturbances such as fire. This work has direct implications for the management and restoration of post-fire erosion and aquatic habitat.  Project outreach and education focused on increasing understanding of geomorphology among non-academic audiences. We developed a set of free, open-access videos about hillslope and river processes targeted toward K-12 educators and the general public (https://www.montana.edu/soils-slopes-streams/) and an interactive Virtual Watershed Sandbox exhibit for the spectrUM Discovery Area science museum. This project also engaged the general public through a series of workshops for middle-school-aged girls, and in activities with a local watershed group. Project activities also supported an early-career scientist, and led to mentorship and advanced training of 6 graduate and 5 undergraduate students.
